text:
(1)
16 to 19 State Street, east side, between Bridge Street and Bowling Green, showing in the foreground, a portion of Battery Park. The house on the extreme left, is the rear of No. 7 Bowling Green, at the S.E. corner of State Street. These houses have long since been demolished, and on its site how (1937), stands the United States Custom House.

About 1861.

Brown Brothers.

(2)
The same, at a later date and showing demolition. On the left appears the rears of houses that face on Bowling Green. Note the Produce Exchange in the background.

Date----?

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1)
16 to 19 State Street, east side, between Bridge Street and Bowling Green, showing in the foreground, a portion of Battery Park. The house on the extreme left, is the rear of No. 7 Bowling Green, at the S.E. corner of State Street. These houses have long since been demolished, and on its site how (1937), stands the United States Custom House.

About 1861.

Brown Brothers.

(2)
The same, at a later date and showing demolition. On the left appears the rears of houses that face on Bowling Green. Note the Produce Exchange in the background.

Date----?

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

State Street, north from Bridge Street to Battery Place, showing the old "El" spur upon same. This carries the Sixth and the Ninth Avenue Elevated Lines to South Ferry. On the left is Battery Park; on the right, the U. S. Custom House; and in the background, the early Washington Building. Behind the latter and facing Bowling Green, is the towering Cunard Building. Broadway begins at that point.

1905

George L. Balgue

Battery Park: A northeastward view towards State Street (elevated line thereon) and showing under construction, at the S.E. corner of that and Bridge Street, the 12-story Battery Park Building.

Ewing Galloway

About 1915.
title: Manhattan: Battery Park - State Street (Northeast).

text:
(1) State Street, east side, south from but not including Pearl Street. The building on the extreme left being No. 12, which adjoins the Cheseborough Building, the corner building at Pearl Street. The 5-story white structure is No. 9, the former Ludlow-Morton House. It is probably the former 3-story basement house, with dormers, that was altered in 1859 and a story added. The 5-story projecting house, No. 7, is the present Mission of Our Lady of the Rosary (Home for Irish Immigrant Girls). It was built about 1800 by Moses Rogers, A. Gardener, & Howland and occupied same in 1830, afterward the Federal Government used it for military purposes during the Civil War. The Pilot Commission were the last occupants prior to the present tenancy. Between these two buildings is No. 8, (formerly known as the Bay House), which was also altered and a story added in 1859; this became the Lutheran Pilgrim House in 1885. Note that this street curves in a southeasterly direction to Whitehall Street, at which point appears the South Ferry Division of the Second and Third Aves. Elevated Lines. These buildings face on Battery Park, which is not shown. May 1925. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) A limited view showing mainly Nos. 9, 8 and 7 (left to right). October 1923. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3) Similar to No. 2, showing a view to Whitehall Street (right). The 6 and 12-story structures, Nos. 6-4 and 3-1 are units of the South Ferry Building, located at the N.E. corner of Whitehall Street. May 1925. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(4) A view showing prominently the R.C. Mission at No. 7. October 1923. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Pearl Street, south side, east from but not including State, to and including Whitehall Streets. (Pearl Street, runs east and west from State Street, to Coenties Slip).

August 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Battery Park: The northwestern corner of same viewed in a westward direction from No. 24 State Street. Note the S.S. Washington about to put to sea.

September 27, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Battery Park - State Street (Northwest).

text:
State Street, east side, south from Bridge (left) to, but not including Whitehall Street, as seen across Battery Park. Prominent structures shown are the Battery Park Building (No. 21-24) and Chesebrough Building (No. 15-19). Note the Sixth and Ninth Ave. Elevated Line curving with State Street towards South Ferry. This set consists of 2 similar views.

July 29, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

State Street, east side, south from Bridge (left) to, but not including Whitehall Street, as seen across Battery Park. Prominent structures shown are the Battery Park Building (No. 21-24) and Chesebrough Building (No. 15-19). Note the Sixth and Ninth Ave. Elevated Line curving with State Street towards South Ferry. This set consists of 2 similar views.

July 29, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
State Street, at Pearl Street and viewing northwestward towards the North (Hudson) River to show the Whitehall Buildings. On the left is Battery Park and the ticket booth of the S.I. ferry. To the right appears the curved front of the Chesebrough Building, No. 15-19 State Street at the S.E. corner of Pearl Street. Note that this thoroughfare veers northwards from this point.

July 4, 1937

P.L.Sperr

(2)
State Street, after "L" demolition, showing the Whitehall Down Town Athletic Club and United Fruit Company Buildings.

P. L. Sperr
May 4, 1941

(3)
State Street near Pearl after "L," demolition, showing Whitehall Building, Down Town Athletic Building and United Fruit Company Buildings.

P. L. Sperr
January 8, 1941

U.S. Custom House
Bowling Green, south to Bridge and State Streets, e. to Whitehall st.
NY: Pach Bros., photographers. n.d.
Original in Rare Book Div.
title: Manhattan: Bowling Green - Bridge Street
